lg.l: The Summer came, and with it drought, Drought. The Illawarra Mercury reported on 8 January 1875 that Drought and want of water are being experienced very much in this district at present, with crops scorched up in all directions and water scarcer in many parts of the district than has been known for years past (p. 2).
The wells were dry, the feed was gone,
Spring’s flowers and blossom promised fruit,
But moisture in the ground was none.
In vain the hungry cattle sought
For grass the empty paunch to fill,
The trifle found was good for nought
Week after week they languished still.
The harvest fields were thin and light,
Half empty heads the cereals waved,
The district round was cheerless sight,
Vainly had labor toiled and slaved.
At length by want and suffering tried,
Their power of durance sunk at last,
The cattle fell around and died,
They died of hunger’s pang and fast,
The astounded farmer views his flocks,
And cherished hope of harvest fled,
The drought at all his striving mocks,
His cattle like his hopes are dead,—
I’d give, said one, a hundred pounds
For half a day of teeming flood,
My gratitude would know no bounds,
Let’s pray to God, for God is good.
Oh! would to Heaven that rain might come,
Would He in mercy send us rain,
Thy will, Almighty, must be done.
‘Twas thus they prayed, and not in vain,
For Heaven the floodgates opened wide,
The downpour came, the drought was gone. Drought was gone. Several items in the Illawarra Mercury in February 1875 reported the drought broken up by rainfall (2 Feb., p. 3; 19 Feb., p. 2).
His thanks the farmer loudly cried,
They ended there, where they begun,
For man is grateful when he needs,
Ungrateful, too, when plenty reigns,
Profuse in promise, not in deeds,
And thankless though enough remains.
